questions.text: Identify the incorrect match of period of growth and corresponding cut-off for ages?
questions.solution:
Option A is incorrect, since Perinatal period extends from 22 weeks gestation till 7 days of postnatal life, according to WHO.

Other options are correct. For details, kindly refer to the detailed video on the app.

questions.text: Which heart disease is most commonly associated with the following abnormality?
questions.solution:
This is an infant with hairy pinna.

  • Hairy pinnais a classical morphological finding seen in infants of diabetic mothers.
  • Among infants of diabetic mothers, VSD is the single most common congenital heart disease, while TGA is the most specific cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: Neonatal reflex which is not present at birth?
questions.solution:
All primitive reflexes are present at birth in a term neonate except

  • Symmetric tonic neck reflex
  • Parachute reflex
  • Landau reflex

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with a history of recurrent UTI and chest infection. The mother recalls that umbilical cord separation occurred at the age of 3 weeks. He suffered from a skin infection, which required admission for IV antibiotics for 2 weeks and plastic surgery on his left shoulder. Neutrophil and monocyte adherence, aggregation and chemotaxis, and phagocytosis demonstrate abnormalities. Autoantibodies and response to vaccination are normal. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Delayed umbilical cord separation after the normal range (up to 3 weeks) is the classic presentation for LAD, esp LAD-I.

  • This is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. It is not associated with defects in lymphocyte or antibody function.
  • There is a failure to express the CD18 integrin, which serves as the receptor for C3b on myeloid and lymphoid cells.
  • LAD is a rare disease. There is marked leukocytosis and localized bacterial infections that are difficult to detect until they have progressed to an extensive life-threatening level.
  • The infections act similarly to those observed in neutropenic patients as a result of the inability of phagocytes to adhere to the endothelium and transmigrate into tissues.
  • In LAD I, lymphocyte functions requiring LFA-1 (the CD2 pathway) are impaired.

choices.text: Trisomy due to meiotic non-disjunction of chromosomes

questions.text: A child had typical clinical characteristics of Down Syndrome and was evaluated for genetic abnormalities. All of the following are the mechanisms of Down Syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Mechanisms of Down Syndrome

  • In approximately 95% of the cases of Down syndrome, there are 3 copies of chromosome 21.The origin of the supernumerary chromosome 21 is maternal in 97% of the cases as a result of errors in meiosis. The majority of these occur in maternal meiosis I (90%).
  • Approximately 1% of persons with trisomy 21 are mosaics, with some cells having 46 chromosomes
  • Another 4% have a translocation that involves chromosome 21. The majority of translocations in Down syndrome are fusions at the centromere between chromosomes 13, 14, 15, 21, and 22, known as robertsonian translocations. The translocations can be de novo or inherited.
  • Very rarely is Down syndrome diagnosed in a patient with only a part of the long arm of chromosome 21 in triplicate (partial trisomy ).
  • Isochromosomes and ring chromosomes are other rarer causes of trisomy 21.
  • Deletions do not produce Down Syndrome

questions.text:
A child presented with multiple small nodular swellings on the body and axillary examination showed hyperpigmentation as shown in the picture. There is a positive family history for these lesions.

Which among the following is the most likely tumour the child will develop?
questions.solution: This child is showing axillary freckling in picture. Nodular swellings may be seen due to neurofibromas. Hence the diagnosis is NF-1.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child has a weight of 12 kg. His urine output is 0.4 ml/kg/hr since last 12 hours and serum creatinine has doubled over the baseline. What is the stage of AKI by KDIGO Criteria?
questions.solution: As the child has the urine output of 0.4ml/kg/hr since last 12 hrs, it is staged as Stage 2 of AKI based on KDIGO staging.

questions.text: A female delivered a 1.2 kg baby prematurely at 31 wk. The child has hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, petechial rash. The child failed neonatal hearing screen. CT scan showed periventricular calcification. Likely congenital infection?
questions.solution:
Clues in the question

  • Preterm delivery
  • Periventricular calcification
  • Hepatosplenomegaly with jaundice
  • Petechial Rash
  • Failure of neonatal hearing screening, indicating likely SNHL

This entire picture corresponds to a likely diagnosis of Congenital CMV Infection.

Remember that petechial rash occurs commonly due to thrombocytopenia in such children.

choices.text: Perform DNA testing for CFTR gene mutations.
Perform a pH probe test for gastroesophageal reflux.
Reassure parents that he does not have CF.
Place him on a high-calorie, high-protein diet.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy has a history of recurrent sinusitis and multiple episodes of pneumonia. You suspect CF and order a sweat chloride test. The sweat electrolyte test result is within the normal range. What is your next step in management?
questions.solution: The child has recurrent upper and lower respiratory tract infections suggesting CF. The sweat chloride test can yield falsely low values, so the next step would be to perform DNA testing to identify any of the common CFTR mutations. Negative sweat chloride test results do not exclude CF.

questions.text: A 9 year old girl presents with difficulty in combing, climbing stairs and erythematous lesions at the MCP joints. Gower Sign is positive. What shall be the next step in diagnostic work-up?
questions.solution:
The girl has features of proximal muscle weakness, in the form of clinical features and a positive Gower sign. She also has erythematous papules at MCP joints, likely due to Gottron papules. This picture suggests a clinical possibility of Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM).

  • Option A: RF has no role in the diagnosis of JDM
  • Option B: Not done in initial work-up in most cases. As per OP Ghai 10th Ed, Muscle biopsy and Electromyography (EMG) are invasive procedures and rarely needed, if other parameters are fulfilled.
  • Option C: No role of NCS in JDM
  • Option D: As per EULAR Criteria of JDM, documenting muscle inflammation by raised muscle enzymes like Serum CK, is needed before we make the final diagnosis. Thus, the next step to do will be to see the Serum CK levels.

questions.text: A 12-month-old male child is brought to your office for a well-child examination and immunizations. You have been following the child since delivery and are aware that he has acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) and a Markedly reduced T-cell count. Which of the following vaccinations should he not receive?
questions.solution:
All of the vaccines mentioned, except varicella, are killed or synthetic vaccines and hence safe in an HIV+/AIDS patient.

  • Regarding live vaccines, OP Ghai Textbook says the following
    • Live vaccines like BCG, OPV, Measles, MMR, Varicella may be given in early stages of HIV Infection (For children aged 5 years and below, CD4+ Count 15% for 6 months or >200/mm3 for 6 months or longer).
    • These live vaccines are unsafe and avoided in advanced HIV or AIDS patients.
    • Where feasible, IPV should be preferred over OPV
    • BCG should also be avoided in any symptomatic HIV patient

questions.text: All of the following are consistent in neonatal sepsis except?
questions.solution:
Children with neonatal sepsis more likely have neutropenia than neutrophilia. Absolute neutrophil count (ANC) less than 1800/mm3 is one of the sepsis screen parameters.

Regarding other options

  • Option A- Feeding difficulties are usually the presenting features of neonatal sepsis
  • Option C- Rise in ESR & CRP is seen in neonatal sepsis
  • Option D- CSF involvement can occur in neonatal sepsis, producing neonatal meningitis. This is more common in late-onset sepsis than early-onset sepsis.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match for the drug used and the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Let us evaluate each option individually

  • Option A is incorrect. Eteplirsen, also known as Exondys-51, is a novel exon-skipping gene therapy, useful in patients of Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy. The drug is FDA approved for DMD patients and is considered a type of ASO= Antisense oligonucleotide agent
  • Option B is correct, Nusinersen is used intrathecally in Spinal Muscular Atrophy and acts by partially activating the SMN-2 gene.
  • Option C is correct. High-dose ACTH is the first-line therapy in patients with West Syndrome.
  • Option D is correct. Everolimus is an mTOR inhibitor, useful in Subependymal Giant Cell Astrocytomas (SEGAs) which are not amenable to surgery.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with complaints of recurrent bleeding. There was also a history of joint pains. There was no mucosal bleeding. Which coagulation factor deficiency can be responsible?
questions.solution:
Mucosal bleed and cutaneous bleeds are more with Platelet defects. Deep tissue bleeding like joint bleed or muscle bleeds are common with clotting factor deficiencies.

  • Hence, best answer among the options with be Factor 8 & 9 deficiency i.e. Hemophilia A and B.

questions.text: A 12-year male with sickle cell disease presents with fever for 2 days and vague complaints of arthralgias. He has a history of multiple sickle cell crises and subsequent admissions. For which of the following infections is this patient at higher risk?
questions.solution:
Patients with splenic dysfunction, whether congenital or acquired, are at higher risk for infections with encapsulated organisms such as S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, H. influenza type b, and Salmonella spp.

  • Sickle cell anemia patients tend to develop Autosplenectomy & splenic function is reduced. This creates an environment for increased risk of infections by the capsulated organisms.
  • Empiric antibiotic coverage for these organisms should include coverage for these when treating a child with splenic dysfunction and fever. In addition, these patients should follow recommendations for vaccination for S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, and H. influenza type b, including polysaccharide 23-valent pneumococcal vaccine and early meningococcal vaccine as well as appropriate boosters.
  • The other organisms listed are not encapsulated and pose no higher risk in patients with splenic dysfunction than in the general population.

questions.text: A neonate delivered at term did not cry immediately at birth. Initial Steps were performed and the child's HR was found to be <100/min. What is the immediate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Any neonate who doesn't cry immediately at birth, needs initial steps including providing warmth and stimulation.

  • In term infants after stimulation, if no respirations are noted, or if the heart rate is <100 beats/min, PPV should be given through a tightly fitted and appropriately sized bag-mask device.
  • PPV should be initiated at pressures of approximately 20 cm H2O at a rate of 40-60 breaths/min initially with 21% fraction of inspired oxygen (FIO2) for full-term infants.

questions.text: The following instrument is useful in a pediatric condition. What is that condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows bed alarm, also called Bell & Pad System, which is one of the 1st line therapy used in Nocturnal Enuresis.

  • These special devices are useful 7 years of age onwards and are effective in 2/3rd patients.
  • Whenever the child gets wet, the sensors in the device make the alarm ring, waking the child. This slowly conditions the child to awaken when bladder is full and void urine.
  • The combination of motivational and alarm therapy is successful in upto 60-70% of patients.
  • Pharmacotherapy using oral desmopressin is used only as a 2nd line treatment, if 1st line measures fail. But have a risk of relapse and side effects.

questions.text: A 2-month-old child was brought to the OPD with swelling over the scalp since birth. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Image shows blood collection in scalp tissue, not extending intracranially. Encephalocele gets ruled out.
  • Subgaleal hemorrhage has acute and morbid presentation and would not present in a routine opd at 2 months.
  • Caput is soft tissue oedema that would disappear in about 48 hours after birth.
  • Cephalhematoma can present over a long time with collection not crossing the suture lines as in this case.
